misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different program than requested
misconceptions.description: Instead of reading a numeric grade and outputting a letter grade using conditional ranges, the student implemented a distance-between-points calculator, so none of the required grade-calculator logic appears.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to think that solving a distance-between-points problem is acceptable for this question, or they confused this problem with a different one.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this task, the program must read a single numeric grade (0–100), use conditionals to determine the correct letter grade based on the specified ranges (A–F), and print that letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a numeric grade.
No conditional statements or grade ranges (90–100, 80–89, etc.) are present.
Output describes the distance between two points rather than a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between assignments or copying code from another exercise without adapting it to the current specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard the distance-calculation logic and write a new program that reads one integer or double grade, uses if/else-if/else to test the numeric ranges for A–F, and prints the appropriate letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program focuses on point coordinates and distance with no trace of grade-related input, conditionals, or output, which clearly conflicts with the problem statement.

evidence.note: The code reads four coordinate values and computes a geometric distance instead of reading a single numeric grade and mapping it to a letter via conditional ranges.

misconceptions.name: Failure to address the assigned problem
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for calculating the distance between two points, which is an unrelated problem, instead of the required Grade Calculator program. None of the required features (single grade input, conditional logic for grading, or letter grade output) are present.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the submitted code for calculating distance between two points fulfills the requirements of the Grade Calculator (Q3).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The student must write code that prompts for and reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and uses if/else if/else structures to assign and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Code reads four double inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one integer/double grade.
Code calculates the square root of squared differences (distance formula).
No conditional logic (if/else structure) is present.
Output reports 'distance' instead of 'Letter grade'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Major misunderstanding of or confusion regarding the assignment specifications (Q3). The student submitted a solution for a different problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always double-check that the code implements the specific requirements outlined in the current problem description. Review the requirements for Q3 and start over, focusing on input, conditional logic, and output for letter grades.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code structure, input mechanism, logic, and output clearly match the distance calculation problem (Pythagorean theorem) and fundamentally fail to address any requirement of the Grade Calculator problem.

evidence.note: The class name suggests the program is for distance calculation, not grade calculation.
The program reads four coordinate inputs instead of a single grade input.

evidence.snippet: double distance = Math.sqrt(dx * dx + dy * dy); // sqrt((x2-x1)^2 + (y2-y1)^2)
evidence.note: The core logic calculates spatial distance, which is irrelevant to grading.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: The output is distance, not a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Completely wrong problem solved
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted code that solves an entirely different problem (calculating distance between two points) instead of the assigned problem (grade calculator). This demonstrates a fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they were asked to write a program that calculates the Euclidean distance between two points.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Code reads x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade value
Code calculates distance using Math.sqrt and Pythagorean theorem
No conditional logic for grade ranges
No letter grade output
Class name is 'DistanceBetweenPoints' instead of something grade-related
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may have copy-pasted code from a different assignment or confused the problem statement with another exercise.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. You need to: (1) read ONE integer grade between 0-100, (2) use if-else statements to check which range it falls into, (3) output the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code solves a completely different problem. There is no ambiguity—the code contains distance calculation logic with no grade logic whatsoever, making this virtually certain.

evidence.note: Student is reading four doubles (coordinates) instead of one integer grade value

evidence.snippet: double distance = Math.sqrt(dx * dx + dy * dy);
evidence.note: Code calculates Euclidean distance, which is completely unrelated to grade conversion

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: Output displays distance instead of letter grade; no letter grade logic present anywhere in code

misconceptions.name: Reads point coordinates instead of a single numeric grade
misconceptions.description: The program reads four doubles representing 2D points (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single numeric grade from 0–100 as required by the specification.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that reading two points (x1, y1, x2, y2) is the required input for this task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt once for a numeric grade (0–100) and read a single number representing that grade.
symptoms: Input prompt asks for 'x1 and y1' and then 'x2 and y2' instead of 'grade'
Program uses four double variables instead of a single grade variable
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have implemented a different problem (distance between two points) instead of the grade calculator.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the coordinate inputs with a single numeric grade input, e.g., prompt 'Enter grade:' and read one number.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The prompts and variables clearly reference coordinates and no grade variable is present.

evidence.note: Reads four doubles labeled as coordinates instead of a single numeric grade.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: No conditional logic implemented for A or B grade ranges
misconceptions.description: The program does not contain any conditional statements to determine whether a numeric grade falls in the A (90–100) or B (80–89) ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that computing the distance between two points is the required behavior and does not attempt any grade range checks.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should use conditional statements (if/else if) to check if the input grade is between 90–100 for A or 80–89 for B.
symptoms: No if, else if, or switch statements anywhere in the code
Computation is purely arithmetic on coordinates, not range checking on a grade
misconceptions.root_cause: The student solved a different problem that does not require any Boolean range checks.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce if/else if statements that compare the grade to 90 and 80 (e.g., if (grade >= 90) ... else if (grade >= 80) ...).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There are no conditional constructs in the file; only arithmetic for distance.

evidence.note: Performs distance calculation instead of any if/else logic for A or B grade ranges.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for C and D
misconceptions.name: No conditional logic implemented for C or D grade ranges
misconceptions.description: The program lacks any logic to test whether a grade is in the C (70–79) or D (60–69) ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student does not appear to consider middle grade ranges at all, focusing only on computing a geometric distance.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: After checking A and B, the program should have additional conditions to check for C (70–79) and D (60–69).
symptoms: No reference to grade values in the 60–79 range
No branching structure to distinguish between C and D ranges
misconceptions.root_cause: Entire grade range handling is omitted because a different problem was implemented.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Extend the if/else if chain to include conditions like else if (grade >= 70) for C and else if (grade >= 60) for D.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is zero code related to grades or their ranges; only distance math is present.

evidence.note: The full main method shows no conditional checks for any grade range, including C and D.

misconceptions.name: No default/else case to handle failing grades (F)
misconceptions.description: The program does not implement any logic to handle grades below 60 as F, nor any default/else branch for out-of-range inputs.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears unaware that all remaining grades (below 60) must map to F and that a default branch is needed.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: After handling A–D ranges, the program should treat any remaining valid grade as F, typically using an else clause.
symptoms: No else or default branch anywhere in the program
No output mentioning F or failing grades
misconceptions.root_cause: Because the student implemented a distance calculator, they did not consider exhaustive coverage of grade categories.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add a final else branch that prints 'F' for any grade not caught by the A–D conditions, and optionally handle invalid inputs.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no conditional structure or any mention of F; the program never categorizes inputs.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: The only output is a distance message; there is no else or default handling for F grades.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Outputs distance instead of a letter grade
misconceptions.description: The program prints the numeric distance between two points rather than mapping a numeric grade to a letter grade A–F.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that the required output is a distance description instead of a letter grade based on input.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should output the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) in a message like 'Letter grade: B'.
symptoms: Output message: 'The distance of the two points is ...'
No mention of 'Letter grade' or any letter grades in the output
misconceptions.root_cause: Misalignment with the problem statement; the student implemented a standard distance formula problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the distance computation and print statement with logic that determines and prints the appropriate letter grade, e.g., 'Letter grade: A'.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only printed output clearly refers to distance, not grades.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: Displays a distance message instead of a letter grade such as 'Letter grade: B'.

The inputs read are coordinates for distance calculation, not a single numeric grade (0-100).

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Solved
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted a solution for calculating the distance between two points (DistanceBetweenPoints) instead of a grade calculator (Q3). This indicates a fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they should write a program that calculates the Euclidean distance between two coordinate points.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q3 requires a program that reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on specified ranges.
symptoms: Code reads four double values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single integer grade
Code calculates distance using the formula sqrt((x2-x1)² + (y2-y1)²)
Code outputs distance value instead of letter grade
Class name is DistanceBetweenPoints instead of GradeCalculator or similar
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either submitted code from a different assignment or did not read/understand the assignment requirements for Q3.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the Q3 problem carefully. The assignment asks for a grade calculator, not a distance calculator. Start fresh with a program that reads a single grade and uses if-else statements to determine and output the appropriate letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code solves an entirely different problem with no overlap in logic. The class name, input/output, and algorithm are all completely misaligned with Q3 requirements.
